unnormalised: Back in '03, when I gave my class 10th board exams, the anxiety was something else. Imagine, months of slogging, tuitions till 9 PM, and the pressure from relatives asking, "Beta, kitne percent expect kar rahe ho?" It was insane!
normalised: Back in two thousand and three, when I gave my class tenth board exams, the anxiety was something else. Imagine, months of slogging, tuitions till nine P-M, and the pressure from relatives asking, "Beta, kitne percent expect kar rahe ho?" It was insane!

unnormalised: My older sister, Diya, had set the bar pretty high with her 92% a few years before. So, naturally, everyone was expecting me to score even higher. My parents, bless their hearts, tried to be supportive, but even their encouragement came with an underlying expectation of a score above 90.
normalised: My older sister, Diya, had set the bar pretty high with her ninety two percent a few years before. So, naturally, everyone was expecting me to score even higher. My parents, bless their hearts, tried to be supportive, but even their encouragement came with an underlying expectation of a score above ninety.

unnormalised: The day the results were announced, the internet was, predictably, slammed. We had to wait till almost 4 PM to even get a glimpse of the website. Finally, after refreshing a hundred times, the page loaded. Roll number entered, and there it was – 87%.
normalised: The day the results were announced, the internet was, predictably, slammed. We had to wait till almost four P-M to even get a glimpse of the website. Finally, after refreshing a hundred times, the page loaded. Roll number entered, and there it was – eighty seven percent.

unnormalised: Honestly, initially, I was disappointed. It wasn’t the 90+ everyone had hoped for. There were subjects where I scored in the 70s, which brought down the overall percentage. My Maths score, especially, was a letdown; I thought I'd ace it, but ended up with just 78.
normalised: Honestly, initially, I was disappointed. It wasn’t the ninety plus everyone had hoped for. There were subjects where I scored in the seventies, which brought down the overall percentage. My Maths score, especially, was a letdown; I thought I'd ace it, but ended up with just seventy eight.

unnormalised: My dad, surprisingly, was calm. He just said, "87 is good, Riya. It’s enough to get you into a good college." Mom, however, was a bit quieter. I could see the disappointment in her eyes. That evening, the entire house felt… subdued.
normalised: My dad, surprisingly, was calm. He just said, "Eighty seven is good, Riya. It’s enough to get you into a good college." Mom, however, was a bit quieter. I could see the disappointment in her eyes. That evening, the entire house felt… subdued.

unnormalised: The real kicker came from my chacha-ji. At dinner, he casually remarked, "Only 87? Diya had more, na?" I wanted to disappear. It felt like all my hard work had been for nothing. That’s when my dadi stepped in.
normalised: The real kicker came from my chacha-ji. At dinner, he casually remarked, "Only eighty seven? Diya had more, na?" I wanted to disappear. It felt like all my hard work had been for nothing. That’s when my dadi stepped in.

unnormalised: She gave chacha-ji a stern look and said, "87 is an excellent score! Not everyone can achieve that. What matters is that she did her best." She then turned to me, squeezed my hand, and said, "Beta, be proud of what you’ve achieved. Percentages aren't everything. In life, things like dedication matter."
normalised: She gave chacha-ji a stern look and said, "Eighty seven is an excellent score! Not everyone can achieve that. What matters is that she did her best." She then turned to me, squeezed my hand, and said, "Beta, be proud of what you’ve achieved. Percentages aren't everything. In life, things like dedication matter."

unnormalised: That night, I realised dadi was right. It wasn't about the numbers on a marksheet. What mattered was the effort, the learning, and the lessons I had gained along the way. Plus, 87% *was* pretty good, and got me into a great college later. Now, looking back, that 87 feels less like a disappointment and more like a stepping stone. It taught me that self-worth isn't tied to a percentage, especially when those numbers are from exams taken at 15 yrs old.
